law.common_name: NYC Automated Employment Decision Tools Law
law.official_citation: NYC Admin. Code § 20-870 et seq.; Local Law 144 of 2021
law.summary: Prohibits employers and employment agencies in New York City from using automated employment decision tools (AEDT) for hiring or promotion unless: (1) the tool has undergone an independent bias audit within one year, (2) audit results are publicly posted, and (3) candidates/employees receive advance notice. Requires testing for disparate impact on protected categories including sex, race, and ethnicity.

definitions.employer: An employer or employment agency that seeks to hire employees who will work in the City of New York, regardless of whether the employer is located within the City.
definitions.employment_agency: Any person undertaking to procure employees or opportunities to work for any employer or to procure for any person opportunities to work as an employee of any employer.
definitions.automated_employment_decision_tool: Any computational process, derived from machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation, that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The tool's output must be used as: (1) the sole criterion; (2) weighted more than other factors; or (3) to overrule human decision-making.

applicability.scope_conditions: Applies to AEDTs used to screen candidates or employees for employment decisions within New York City, including hiring for new positions or promotion to new roles. Covers tools that substantially assist or replace human discretionary decision-making.
exemptions: Tools where AI output is merely one equal factor among many (not determinative)
Tools where human decision-makers can freely overrule the AI recommendation without the AI output being weighted more heavily
Anti-fraud detection tools not used for employment decisions
Narrow AI performing clearly defined tasks like resume parsing without scoring candidates
applicability.geographic_trigger: Using an AEDT to evaluate candidates or employees who will work in New York City, regardless of employer location

obligations.requirement_text: An employer or employment agency may not use an automated employment decision tool unless a bias audit of the tool was conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool.
obligations.plain_language: You must conduct an independent bias audit of any AEDT within 12 months before using it for hiring or promotion decisions.

obligations.requirement_text: The bias audit must be conducted by an independent auditor. An independent auditor means a person or group that is capable of exercising objective and impartial judgment on all issues within the scope of a bias audit of an automated employment decision tool.
obligations.plain_language: The bias audit must be performed by an independent third party with no financial interest in your company or the AEDT vendor.

obligations.requirement_text: A bias audit shall include testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code (EEO-1 categories: sex, race/ethnicity).
obligations.plain_language: The bias audit must test for disparate impact on sex and race/ethnicity categories, including intersectional groups (e.g., Hispanic women, Asian men), using selection rates or scoring rates.

obligations.requirement_text: Before using an automated employment decision tool, an employer or employment agency shall make publicly available on its website a summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool, including the distribution date of the tool to which the results apply.
obligations.plain_language: You must publicly post a summary of the bias audit results on your website before using the AEDT, including selection rates and impact ratios for each demographic category.

obligations.requirement_text: At least 10 business days before the use of an automated employment decision tool, an employer or employment agency shall provide a notice to all candidates for employment or promotion who reside in the city that an automated employment decision tool will be used in connection with the assessment or evaluation of such candidates.
obligations.plain_language: You must notify candidates or employees at least 10 business days before using an AEDT, and provide this notice via job posting, employment section of website, or direct communication.

obligations.requirement_text: The notice to candidates shall include the job qualifications and characteristics that the automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of such candidate or employee and information about the type of data collected for the automated employment decision tool.
obligations.plain_language: You must tell candidates what qualifications and characteristics the AEDT evaluates and what types of data it collects about them.

obligations.requirement_text: An employer or employment agency that uses an automated employment decision tool shall provide to each candidate or employee information about the employer's or employment agency's data retention policy as applied to the automated employment decision tool and shall provide an alternative selection process or accommodation for any individual who requests one.
obligations.plain_language: You must inform candidates about your data retention policies for the AEDT and offer an alternative selection process or reasonable accommodation upon request.

penalties.enforcing_body: NYC Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP)
penalties.notes: DCWP enforces via civil penalties. Violations include: (1) using an AEDT without a current bias audit, (2) failing to publicly post audit results, (3) failing to provide 10-day advance notice to candidates, (4) failing to disclose qualifications/characteristics and data collection, (5) failing to provide alternative selection process upon request. Each day of non-compliance constitutes a separate violation. Complaints can be filed through DCWP's online portal.

cross_references.notes: Colorado AI Act applies to high-risk AI systems (broader than employment) and requires impact assessments and risk management programs but does not mandate independent bias audits. NYC LL144 is narrower (employment only) but requires specific annual bias audits with public disclosure of disparate impact metrics.

Illinois Artificial Intelligence Video Interview Act (AIVIRA, effective Jan 1, 2026) regulates AI use in employment decisions under the Illinois Human Rights Act. Like NYC LL144, it requires bias testing and notice to candidates, but applies statewide rather than city-specific.

California CCPA amendments regarding automated decision-making technology focus on consumer privacy rights (opt-out, access, deletion) rather than bias audits. NYC LL144 focuses on anti-discrimination testing. Both require transparency but serve different regulatory objectives.

change_log.description: Local Law 144 of 2021 signed into law by NYC Mayor.
DCWP publishes proposed rules to implement Local Law 144, including definition of independent auditor and bias audit requirements.

DCWP issues final rules (6 RCNY § 5-300 et seq.) after public comment period, clarifying AEDT definition, independent auditor qualifications, bias audit methodology (selection rates, impact ratios), and notice requirements. Enforcement date delayed from April 15, 2023 to July 5, 2023.
DCWP begins active enforcement of Local Law 144 and implementing regulations. Civil penalties of $500-$1,500 per day per violation now applicable.
